quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 10 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 10.9: Electrolytic Cells and Electrolysis
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Using electrical energy to drive non-spontaneous reactions

questions.question: Which of the following is the primary difference between a Galvanic cell and an Electrolytic cell?
options: Electrolytic cells require an external power source to drive a non-spontaneous reaction
Electrolytic cells produce electricity from a spontaneous reaction
Oxidation occurs at the cathode in an electrolytic cell
Electrolytic cells do not require electrodes
questions.explanation: Galvanic cells are batteries that provide power; electrolytic cells are devices that consume power to force a chemical change.

questions.question: In an electrolytic cell, the Anode is assigned a ________ charge.
questions.explanation: Because the external battery pulls electrons away from the anode, it becomes positively charged in an electrolytic setup (the opposite of a Galvanic cell).

questions.question: What is 'Electroplating'?
options: Using electrolysis to deposit a thin layer of metal onto the surface of another object
Cleaning a metal surface using high-voltage sparks
Melting a metal to form a new alloy
Measuring the voltage of a standard battery
questions.explanation: By making the object to be plated the cathode, metal ions in the solution are reduced and form a solid metallic coating on the object.

questions.question: When electrolyzing molten $NaCl$, what product is formed at the cathode?
questions.explanation: At the cathode, reduction occurs. $Na^{+}$ ions gain electrons to become solid sodium metal.

questions.question: According to Faraday's Law of Electrolysis, the mass of a substance produced at an electrode is directly proportional to:
options: The total quantity of electrical charge (Coulombs) passed through the cell
The size of the beaker used
The concentration of the salt bridge
questions.explanation: The more electrons (charge) you push through the system, the more moles of ions you can reduce or oxidize.

questions.question: What is the formula used to calculate the total charge ($Q$) passed through an electrolytic cell?
questions.explanation: Charge (Coulombs) is the product of current in Amperes (Coulombs per second) and time in seconds.

questions.question: In the electrolysis of **aqueous** $NaCl$, why is $H_{2}$ gas produced at the cathode instead of sodium metal?
options: Water is easier to reduce than $Na^{+}$ ions
Sodium metal reacts too quickly with the glass
Chlorine gas prevents sodium from forming
Sodium ions are too large to reach the electrode
questions.explanation: In aqueous solutions, there is a competition. Since water has a more positive reduction potential than $Na^{+}$, it is reduced first, producing hydrogen gas and $OH^{-}$.

questions.question: How many moles of electrons are required to produce 1 mole of Aluminum metal from $Al^{3+}$ ions?
questions.explanation: The reduction half-reaction is $Al^{3+} + 3e^{-} \rightarrow Al(s)$. Therefore, 3 electrons are needed for every 1 atom of Al.

questions.question: If a current of 2.0 A is passed through a cell for 100 seconds, what is the total charge $Q$?
Which industrial process uses electrolysis to extract aluminum from bauxite ore?
questions.explanation: The Hall-Héroult process involves the electrolysis of aluminum oxide dissolved in molten cryolite.

scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: $Q = I \cdot t$ is essential for these problems!
